title: What will happen if an asteroid hits Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: Depends upon a few factors, such as the size, speed, hit angle and landing point. If it is 10 feet across, it may skip off of the atmosphere or create a pretty fireworks explosion in the sky. If it’s 100 feet across, it may cause a massive explosion, like the one at Tunguska. If its a quarter mile wide, it could take out an entire region, but if its 10km wide, well, that's a game changer for just about anyone and any living thing walking or crawling the Earth. That's what we may call an ELE, or Extinction-level Event, and it doesn't really matter where it hits. The deepest point in the oceans is only 11 km deep, and a typical speed for impacting. bolides is around 30 kilometers per second (around 90 times the speed of sound) -could be slower or faster. Unlike smaller meteors, an asteroid that size will not be slowed down much by the atmosphere. It will punch through in less than 3 seconds like it's hardly even there. And when it reaches the surface, it will hit so hard that it won't matter if it strikes ocean or land. Most people within a hundred miles or so of the impact point will either drop dead from the concussion of the compression wave of the incoming bolide, or will be completely vaporized. They will most like never know what hit them, but they're the lucky ones… The energy of the impact will also vaporize a large amount of the Earth's crust, possibly creating a crater more than one hundred kilometers across, throwing all that rock and dirt (known as ‘ejecta') into the air. The outrush of air from the impact with cause winds reaching out up to a thousand miles, with wind speeds that may exceed 900 miles per hour. If you are near a coast, and the bolide hits mid-ocean, wave depths near the shore may reach over a mile in height and travel hundreds of miles inland. Horrible, unimaginable earthquakes will be felt worldwide, and the sound of the impact will reach out thousands of miles, serving as a warning regarding the real hell that is about to come. Some of the ejecta will be going so fast that it will fly right out of the Earth's atmosphere and go into orbit around the Earth. But most of it will rain back down on the Earth. - The entire Earth, heating the atmopshere to temperatures possibly near 900 degrees (hot enough to melt lead). This heat will last several hours and feel like the inside of an oven. It will trigger forest fires and cook anyone or anything that isn't sheltered deep underground. Your house and even your clothes may likely spontaneously combust. You will not survive, but you're probably luckier than the few people who will, because the ugliness is still just beginning… The combination of dust from the impact, and soot from the forest fires will remain in the Earth's atmosphere for a year or so, blocking the light of the Sun. Without sunlight, much of the Earth's plantlife will die. The entire food chain will collapse. Many species of animals--including the human race, if we aren't both lucky and resourceful!--will die out, either in the initial catastrophe, or in the ensuing years due to lack of food and the general devastation of the environment. And if you are fortunate enough to survive all of the above, you and the other survivors, which may number less than 50,000 or even 20,000 of the nearly 7 billion we currently have, will literally be reduced to stone age living for a time. You and the other survivors will scrounge just to continue to exist, eating anything that comes your way. All in all, if you survive such an impact, the next few years of your life won't be your best.

Asteroids are hitting the Earth all the time. Every day, space bombards us with around 100 tonnes of dust and sand. Car-sized asteroids make it to our atmosphere about once a year. Lucky for us, they burn up in the mesosphere, never reaching the Earth’s surface. The massive 10-kilometer wide, life-threatening rocks like the one that wiped out all the dinosaurs, don’t come by too often – maybe once every few million years. The ones we do have to worry about are asteroids the size of a football field that actually make it to the Earth’s surface. Meteorites. They tend to come down to Earth every 2,000 years. What if one of those was to hit us tonight? The extent of an asteroid’s devastation to our planet all comes to where the it lands. Just 3% of Earth’s surface is populated, that means, in all likelihood, 97 asteroids out of 100 would just plunge into the ocean or flatten an uninhabited forest somewhere in Siberia or northern Canada. Damage to humans would be close to nothing. But 3 out of every 100 asteroids would strike a populated city. Imagine seeing a 100-meter-long (330-foot) rock speeding towards you, traveling at 30 km (19 miles) per second… From the moment it passed unharmed through the mesosphere, it would take less than 3 seconds for it to crash down to Earth. For a city like New-York, it would mean over 2.5 million casualties. A huge firefall would destroy everything in a 3 km (2 mile) radius, and cause heavy damage to buildings within a 7 km (4.5 miles) radius. Maybe it’s not all bad… Ever heard of the meteorite that slammed near the Russia’s city of Chelyabinsk? That rock exploded with the force of 20 Hiroshima bombs and caused around $33 million worth of damage. Some of those losses were recovered by ingenious Russians selling meteorite pieces for up to $50 a gram. Well, in our scenario, the meteorite is 5 times bigger! The freshly fallen space rock may pose the risk of widespread radiation if it were made up of radioactive heavy metals. Of course, it wouldn’t be as bad as a 10-kilometer wide asteroid hitting the Earth. In that case, the shock wave would be enough to wipe out a a good chunk of humanity right away. The Earth would get a new crater over a 100 km (62 miles) across and a ring of asteroid debris would give us a ‘Saturn-like’ appearance. Most of this debris would rain back on Earth, setting cities… and forests on fire on fire and cooking everything that’s not protected. You might want to invest in an underground bunker before this happens. Because on the surface, it would be very, very dusty. All this dust and smoke would block the sunlight. Without the sun, all plants and a lot of animals would die out. After about a year, the atmosphere would clear up, but there would be very little food for humans left. And if we weren’t resourceful enough, this would be the end of our race. We would suffer the same fate as the dinosaurs did 65 million years ago.

Nothing or something. It all depends on the mass of said asteroid, its composition, and obviously its speed. There are asteroids out there that are no more than basically sand gathered together. Or at least particles of rock. Those asteroids easily break up in the Earth atmosphere. Those most dangerous asteroids are those with a high content of iron, and other heavy elements. But in the end it all comes down to mass and speed. For example the Tunguska forest suffered a devastation, caused by what was believed to be an asteroid of significant size, that blew up mid air before it crashed.   The asteroid is believed to have exploded 5 to 10 kilometers before hitting the ground. And still it leveled everything in a radius of 2,150 Km². If such event happened today over a major city in the world, we would see hundreds of thousands to millions of dead, in mere seconds.   Events like those or the dinosaurs and other extinction events, happen very far apart from one another. Still it could happen at any time and we would have little to almost no warning. Most astronomers look for tell tale signs like the asteroid when it approaches the inner solar system, that the ice in it will begin to melt and form a tail that we can see. But that doesn't necessarily needs to happen. If the asteroid is made up of almost no ice, and mostly of rock, iron and other elements. Then it may not form any tail whatsoever. Which would make it incredibly difficult to detect. One such asteroid could be coming our way right now, and we would be none the wiser. At least not until it was too late. Obviously if it's mass is small then it would never be a significant danger. But if it's something the size of a city or several kilometers wide, then it can help end almost all life on the planet.

What do you mean, “if”? Earth is pummelled by hundreds if not thousands of meteorites a day. Most go unnoticed because they are micrometeroites that burn up almost instantaneously on contact with a thick enough layer of the Earth’s atmosphere. Others go unnoticed because they happen on the day side of the planet where the sky is lit up by the Sun. The vast majority never reach the Earth’s solid surface. Of those that do, most are the size of gravel or small stones. Fewer still are the size of small sports balls, baseballs, footballs, etc. Rarer still are the ones that make the news by happening at night and being large enough to leave a large enough streak of light in the sky to get put on YouTube. The really rare ones are the Tunguska and Chelyabink meteors that are seen during the day and actually produce damage on the ground. The truly astronomicly unlikely ones are the kind that produce extinction level events here on Earth, such as the one responsible for the Chicxulub crater, which is thought to have killed off the dinosaurs. Once it was realized that the surface of the Earth, unlike the Moon, is regularly scoured by wind and water erosion, it was soon recognized that the Earth is at least as pock-marked by meteor impact craters as our natural satellite. 11 Fascinating Impact Craters on Earth Possibly the most famous impact crater on the Earth’s surface, other than Chicxulub, would be Barringer Crater in Arizona.  This is what people tend to think of when they think meteor impact crater, but once scientists figured out what to look for, they started finding craters all over the Earth’s surface. What would happen if a meteorite hits the Earth? Well, recently one meteorite made a hole in a frozen lake. You can see people standing around the hole for scale:  The 2013 Chelyabinsk meteor wasn’t very impressive as a meteorite (the bits that hit Earth), but as meteor (still in the air) it injured almost 1500 Russians, shattered windows, and collapsed old buildings. The meteor’s air blast was estimated as 400 - 500 kilotons.  (Pictured: shattered windows in Chelyabinsk. A lot of Russians got glass in the face.)  However, the Chelyabinsk meteor was rather small, only about 12,500 tons when it hit Earth’s atmosphere. The Barringer Crater in Arizona was larger. The energy release at impact (50,000 years ago) was about 10 megatons. It was not a world-shaking impact, but it was devastating in the region: Barringer Meteor Crater and Its Environmental Effects  The damage inflicted by the impact was similar to a nuclear bomb blast, but without ionizing radiation damage. The asteroid, bedrock, and any fauna or flora at ground zero would have been vaporized. Bedrock was ejected and overturned out to a distance of 1-2 km (see graphic). The explosive shockwave would have produced winds in excess of 1000 km/hr within 3 to 5 km of the impact (see effects map). These winds would have stripped away grass near the crater and flattened juniper and pinyon trees out to a radial distance of ~14 to 19 km. Branches, rocks, and other debris was also accelerated by the blast, causing shrapnel-type wounds out to a distance of 10 to 13 km. Vegetation and animals may also have been subject to the thermal emission from the blast, causing burn damage out to a maximum range of ~10km. The probable sum of these effects is the destruction of vegetation over an area 800 to 1500 km.

Much of it depends on its size, composition, net velocity and point of impact. The most important thing to keep in mind is that the mass of an object increases with the cube of its size. Thus, a 10-meter diameter object will weigh 1000 times (10x10x10) as much as a one-meter object. Likewise, a 100-meter diameter object will weigh 1000 times as much as a 10-meter object. As a result, the kinetic energy of a moving object (and thus its impact energy) increases exponentially as it gets bigger. Objects a few meters across burn up in the upper atmosphere. Objects a few tens of meters across penetrate deeper and explode closer to the ground (like Chelyabinsk), potentially causing damage on the ground. Objects hundreds of meters in size can impact the ground and cause tremendous damage to the immediate area. Objects that are kilometers across… miles across… will have potentially planet-wide catastrophic consequences, possibly lasting for years. A lot hinges on the details of course, but as they say… “size does matter"!

Way too many variables to count. We need to define “huge.” Not only do I need to know the size of the asteroid, but we need to know its composition (it affects density, which, combined with volume, affects mass), its velocity, its angle of impact, and the location of impact. Let me put it this way: An asteroid that’s about 50 meters across, made of iron, traveling at 25 to 30 km/s and impacting the ocean would have a much wider range of impact than an asteroid of the same size that was made of light, porous rock and traveling at 20 km/s and hitting land. Put another way, the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs 65 million years ago (after triggering earthquakes and volcanoes on a global scale, setting the planet on fire, and triggering a nuclear winter) was about 6 miles across, and it theoretically hit at a speed of at least 20 km/s (45,000 mph). If we doubled the diameter of the asteroid, it’d have a mass that is approximately 8 times greater, thus if we kept the speed the same, the KE of the impact would be 8 times greater, and thus the destruction would be much larger. We’d likely go from “killing dinosaurs/humans” to “killing the planet.” So, we need to be more specific about the size of the asteroid and its composition at least.
